transit_308_description:
Provides public bus transportation to serve the diverse needs of the community. Reduced fares available to individuals with disabilities and to those over the age of 65 as well. All vehicles are lift equipped to serve those with mobility equipment. Bus transportation is offered in the cities of Ojai, Oxnard, Port Hueneme, Ventura and in the unincorporated County areas between the cities.

-Call or visit website for more information on reduced fares and current bus schedules.

Customer Service is available for all questions Monday to Friday from 7:00am-7:00pm.
paratransit_363_description:
The City of Moorpark offers individually scheduled transportation services for seniors age 65+ and disability related transportation for those with an Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) Certification.

CORONAVIRUS SPECIFIC STATUS UPDATE:

Service is continuing.



ELIGIBILITY:
Eligibility for Moorpark disability-related transportation:
Services individuals with disabilities of any age with ADA certification. (If you have a temporary or permanent, physical, mental, visual, cognitive, or other disability or limitation that would impact your ability to access a fixed route bus service, you may be eligible for ADA Certification. See the section at the bottom of this entry for more information for how to apply for ADA certification.)
Eligibility for Moorpark Senior Transportation:
Individuals aged 65 and over qualify for Dial-A-Ride transportation as seniors. Seniors with a disability are welcome to apply for ADA certification.

SERVICE ANIMALS
Service animals are allowed on vehicles.

SERVICE AREA:
All rides must 1) start and end in Moorpark, 2) transfer to the Los Angeles ACCESS or fixed route bus system, or 3) transfer to VISTA bus service. Other trips between Moorpark and other cities would use the ECTA Connect Dial-A-Ride service.



RESERVATIONS: Once enrolled in the program, call at least two hours prior to needing the ride if there is no mobility device (i.e. wheelchair). Call at least a day in advance if rider will have a mobility device. When calling, let the dispatcher know that you are a Moorpark Dial-A-Rider.

TRANSFERS:
In order to transfer outside of the City of Moorpark, passengers must go through the East County Transit Alliance (ECTA).
East County Transit Alliance (ECTA) services InterCity CONNECT Dial-A-Ride which is a shared ride transportation service available in most of eastern Ventura County and is specifically designed to permit travel outside local Dial-A-Ride service areas.
•Reservations can be made by calling ECTA, dispatcher will assist in organizing trip.
•Transfers to Los Angeles are available
•ECTA fares are $6.00

APPLICATION PROCESS:
•Disability-related – See below for more information on applying for ADA.
•Senior-related - Contact Simi Valley Transit.

DOCUMENTS REQUIRED:
•For disability-related eligibility: ADA card, which is issued upon completion of ADA application (See below for more information).
•For eligibility as a senior: Proof of age (65 and over).

FARES: Travel within the city of Moorpark: $2.00

PHONES:
•Questions/concerns about the Dial-A-Ride program: 805-517-6257
•Reservations/ECTA: 805-375-5467
•VCTC ADA Application: 888-667-7001

SERVICES OFFERED IN FOLLOWING LANGUAGES:
English, Spanish

WHAT IS ADA CERTIFICATION:The Americans with Disabilities Act is a federal law which prohibits discrimination based on disability in employment, public services, transportation, public accommodations, and telecommunications. The transportation section of the ADA requires that fixed route transportation systems must be accessible to those with disabilities. The law also provides for complementary paratransit service if the buses are not accessible or if your disability or condition prevents you from using fixed-route public transportation.
REQUIREMENTS FOR ADA CERTIFICATION: Individual must have a temporary or permanent disability that prevents the rider from using fixed route bus service. The disability may need to be verified by a healthcare professional. 
TO APPLY FOR ADA CERTIFICATION: Individuals seeking ADA certification can complete an application online at https://www.goventura.org/getting-around/ada-certification/ or call Mobility Management Partners (MMP) at 888-667-7001 to apply.   An in person assessment may be required once application is submitted.
paratransit_321_description:
ECTA CONNECT InterCity Dial-A-Ride is a shared ride transportation service available in most of eastern Ventura County that provides travel between local dial-a-ride service areas. ECTA service exists to complement, but not replace, local, city-specific paratransit services. For this reason, ECTA provides only intercity service, meaning trips must cross a city limit. Trips are not provided within the same city limit or between Thousand Oaks and Westlake Village (which are provided by local dial-a-ride services in each community).



CORONAVIRUS SPECIFIC STATUS UPDATE:

Service is continuing.



ELIGIBILITY

•Seniors age 65 and older

•Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) certified individuals



For ECTA Disability Related Transportation: If you have a temporary or permanent disability that would prevent you have using a fixed route bus service and which can be verified by a healthcare professional, you may be eligible for ADA Certification. See the section at the bottom of this entry for more information for how to apply for ADA certification.

SERVICE ANIMALS
Service animals are allowed on vehicles.

SERVICE AREA:

ECTA service is available to residents of the Cities of Moorpark, Simi Valley, Thousand Oaks, Westlake Village, and Ventura County unincorporated areas inside the city limits of these cities (referred to as Primary Service Area).



RESERVATIONS:
Reservations are required at least one day in advance of travel, and may be made up to two weeks in advance. Subscriptions for recurring trips may be requested (subject to capacity limits). Each reservation must be at least one hour apart.
Reservation Center Hours:
•Monday-Friday 5:30am-7:30pm
•Saturday-Sunday 7:30am-7:30pm
•On the day of your trip, please be ready 15 minutes prior to scheduled pick-up time. Drivers will wait a maximum of 5 minutes before departing even when they arrive up to 15 minutes early.

TRANSFERS: Trips to the Go Access area (via Camarillo access point) are arranged Monday-Saturday. Transfers to Los Angeles County via LA Access service area are available, but are only for ADA cardholders. Additional information during the reservation process will be required.

APPLICATION PROCESS:

•Call for trip reservations.

DOCUMENTS REQUIRED

•Proof of age (65+) or ADA (Americans with Disabilities) certification card

FARE:
•$6.00 each way
•Passengers may bring a companion, and full fare will be required as well. ADA cardholders may bring a Personal Care Assistant (PCA) at no additional charge.

PHONE

•Main Number: 805-375-5467 •Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) Inquiries: 888-667-7001

LANGUAGES

English and Spanish, translation services available for all other languages.

*Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) Certification*

WHAT IS ADA CERTIFICATION: The Americans with Disabilities Act is a federal law which prohibits discrimination based on disability in employment, public services, transportation, public accommodations, and telecommunications. The transportation section of the ADA requires that fixed route transportation systems must be accessible to those with disabilities. The law also provides for complementary paratransit service if the buses are not accessible or if your disability or condition prevents you from using fixed-route public transportation.

REQUIREMENTS FOR ADA CERTIFICATION: Individual must have a temporary or permanent disability that prevents the rider from using fixed route bus service. The disability must be verified by a healthcare professional.

TO APPLY FOR ADA CERTIFICATION:

Individuals seeking ADA certification can complete an application online at https://www.goventura.org/getting-around/ada-certification/ or call Mobility Management Partners (MMP) at 888-667-7001 to apply. An in person assessment must be done once application is submitted

paratransit_362_description:
Provides door-through-door transportation for non-emergency medical transport and for activities of daily living (including shopping, banking, etc) to residents of the Camarillo Health Care District residents.



Drivers are trained in CPR and First Aid, and have additional training in transporting frail, elderly cognitively-challenged and mobility-challenged riders. Vehicles are equipped with hydraulic lifts to accommodate wheelchair clients, oxygen canisters, and other assistive mobility devices. If you require wheelchair transport, a standard wheelchair can be provided during your ride. Vehicles are not equipped to carry electric wheelchairs, scooters, or other similarly heavy chairs.



CORONAVIRUS SPECIFIC STATUS UPDATE:
Service is continuing as normal; however there will be requirements before boarding on vehicle:
•Your temperature will be checked via contactless thermometer, by the driver, before you enter the vehicle. Your temperature reading must be less than 100 degrees farenheit to enter the vehicle.
•You will be asked if you are experiencing symptoms of COVID-19.
•You will be required to sign a waiver before transportation service is rendered.
•Social distancing requirements limit the number of passengers that may travel at one time. Please be prepared to sit where the driver instructs you to sit and remain in that seat until your ride is complete.
•The vehicle is appropriately sanitized after each ride.

ELIGIBILITY:
Care-A-Van is open to all residents age 18 and older.

SERVICE AREA:

Rides must start within District boundaries which includes the Greater Camarillo Area, Somis, and parts of the Las Posas and Santa Rosa Valleys. Destination anywhere in Ventura County. Fares will vary depending on the city passenger is traveling to:



RESERVATIONS:

It is strongly recommended to make a reservation at least 2-3 days in advance. Same day service may be possible based on availability. Trips outside operating hours may be accommodated under special circumstances.


•Credit card payment can be received by telephone for a convenient, cash-free ride.
•You will be asked to provide your name, telephone number, pick-up location, destination and what time you need to be there, if you need wheelchair assistance and what type of wheelchair

APPLICATION PROCESS:
No application required.

DOCUMENTS REQUIRED:
None.

FARES:
•Camarillo: $20 (one way)
•Oxnard: $25 (one way)
•Ventura: $30 (one way)
•Caregiver rides free

PHONES:
Main number: 805-388-2529

CAMARILLO HEALTHCARE DISTRICT OFFICE HOURS:
8:00am-4:30pm

paratransit_45_description:
Free Transportation for Seniors & Persons with Disabilities
Hyde Shuttles is a service of Sound Generations, a comprehensive non-profit organization that serves older adults and adults with disabilities in King County. Hyde Shuttle provides door-to-door van service throughout King County. Our friendly, caring drivers transport riders to and from medical appointments, the pharmacy, senior centers, grocery stores, a friend’s house, and every location you need.
paratransit_29_description: Northshore Senior Center provides on-demand, door-to-door accessible transportation services for older adults and people with disabilities living in the North King County/South Snohomish County region. Rides to medical care, groceries, or activities at their senior centers prevent isolation and improve riders' quality of life.
transit_7_description:
The American Cancer Society Road To Recovery program provides transportation to and from treatment for people with cancer who do not have a ride or are unable to drive themselves. Patients must be traveling to an appointment required to begin or complete cancer treatment, or to an appointment for complementary therapy during cancer treatment. Transportation cannot be provided for follow-up appointments after treatment has been completed. Patients under the age of 18 must be accompanied by a legally responsible adult such as a parent or caregiver. Interpretation is available upon booking your appointment, but it is not guaranteed that your driver will be fluent in your language.

The service primarily employs Volunteer Drivers, but in the circumstance where none are available they can send out a taxi to come pick a rider up.

All clients must be ambulatory.
transit_9_description:
Catholic Community Services is proud to provide door-through-door service to low-income elders and adults with disabilities. This page focuses on the program operating in Snohomish County, but each have the same general requirements. People who can use the service must be:

A low-income elder (those age 60 and over) and/or an adult with disabilities (temporary or permanent)
People who cannot pay for services
People who do not qualify for state-paid services
And, people who do not have family and friends available to help them.
paratransit_18_description:
Homage Transportation Assistance Program (TAP) provides a special needs transportation for older adults and people with disabilities outside the Community Transit Dial-a-Ride (DART) service area. TAP connects people to services, health care, senior centers, shopping, recreation and more.

We go any place that Community Transit DART or Everett Paratransit doesn't go. (Rural areas)

Call today to complete the application process and find out if you are eligible.

https://wsdot.wa.gov/travel/washington-state-ferries/rider-information/riders-disabilities
Learn about how we're providing equal access to our riders with disabilities, including information about discounted fares, service animals and more.

We are committed to providing equal access to our riders with disabilities. All our facilities are accessible to people with disabilities, though there are varying levels of accessibility on our ferries based on vessel type.

Ferry and terminal accessibility
All our ferries and terminals are accessible to riders with disabilities.

If an elevator, accessible restroom or other accessibility feature is out of service on one of our ferries or terminals, we post a notification on our travel alert bulletins page. You can also sign up for route-specific travel alerts to get notification of elevator outages and other information that could affect your trip.

If you have questions about your travel, give our team a call at 206-464-6400. We can recommend sailing times and identify vessels and terminals that best accommodate your needs.

South Sound 2-1-1, in collaboration with community agencies and local transit agencies, helps to coordinate transportation resources throughout Pierce, Thurston, and Lewis Counties. The Downtown Circulator is a free, fixed-route shuttle bus that connects riders to various health and human service providers downtown.

Who can ride the Downtown Circulator?

The Downtown Circulator is a free, ADA-accessible service for everyone. There are no eligibility requirements and you do not need a ticket to ride the Circulator.

Where and When Does the Downtown Circulator Go?

The Downtown Circulator runs from 7am to 4pm, Monday to Friday, on a fixed, one-way, 30-minute loop. Look for our green Circulator bus stop signs downtown!
For more information, text INFORM to 206-753-4801 for ongoing updates and support in multiple languages.
transit_42_description:
As a part of the Snoqualmie Valley Transportation, the Valley Shuttle is a deviated fixed-route bus. The Valley Shuttle circulates throughout Snoqualmie Valley but also has the ability to deviate from the regular route and do door-to-door service if two hours of advance notice is given. The shuttle connects riders to Metro bus stops between North Bend, Snoqualmie, Fall City, Carnation, and Duvall. To see the Valley Shuttle Map and Timetable click here.

To use this service, simply stand at one of the many Metro bus stops. When the bus comes, make sure to confirm with the driver if the shuttle is northbound or south bound. The driver will announce stops verbally as they arrive. If you are in Duvall or North Bend and you need the bus to deviate from its regular route, please call in advance and SVT will try to arrange it for you.

Each Valley Shuttle has a bike rack.
You may call Snoqualmie Valley Transportation at least 2 hours ahead in advance and they will accommodate deviations as the schedule allows.

About Beyond the Borders
Beyond the Borders transportation service helps eligible riders in east and south Pierce County, who are outside of the Pierce Transit service area, access public transit, medical services, employment and shopping. transit_34_description:
Pierce Transit is an operator of public transit in Pierce County, Washington. More than 900 miles of fixed routes are served by Pierce Transit buses.

ORCA LIFT COMING SOON
TO PIERCE TRANSIT!
On February 13, 2023, the Pierce Transit Board of Commissioners approved a proposal to have Pierce Transit join the ORCA LIFT fare program. Effective April 1, 2023, Pierce Transit will accept ORCA LIFT adult fare payment on bus and Runner services.

What is ORCA LIFT?
ORCA LIFT is a reduced adult fare program that is offered to individuals that meet the eligibility requirements up to or equal to 200 percent of the current Federal Poverty Level Guidelines*. If you qualify, you will be able to pay $1 per one-way trip on the following transit agencies’ services:

Sound Transit Services such as ST Express, Link Light Rail, Sounder Commuter Rail
King County Metro Buses, Seattle Streetcar
Kitsap Transit buses
Everett Transit buses
And NOW Pierce Transit buses and Runner services link
https://www.piercetransit.org/orcalift/

transit_41_description:
Skagit Transit History and Demographics
Skagit Transit System was established under RCW 36.57A. The authority was established in 1993 by voter approval of 2/10 of 1% local sales tax to support transit service in the Mount Vernon/Burlington area. Since initial voter approval in 1993, expansion of the Public Transit Benefit Area (PTBA) or service area occurred through public vote in Anacortes, La Conner, Sedro-Woolley, Lyman, Hamilton, and Concrete.

Voters in unincorporated South Fidalgo Island, Burlington Country Club, North and Northwest Skagit County approved transit expansion into their areas also. At present time the PTBA covers approximately 750 square miles of Skagit County. In November 2008, voters approved an additional 2/10 of 1% to support transit service in the Skagit PTBA. Skagit Transit currently receives a total of 4/10 of 1% local sales tax, operates 17 fixed routes (includes 3 commuter routes), complimentary paratransit services and has over 45 vanpool groups in operation.
paratransit_43_description:
Door-to-Door Service
“Door to Door” means it is a non-fixed route that requires advance scheduling by the rider. We pick you up at a location such as your home and take you to your destination.  Also referred to as a shared-ride service, the daily routes vary and are dictated by the requests from our riders. The service area for this includes North Bend, Snoqualmie, Fall City, Preston (most of), Carnation, Duvall, and Monroe.

This service is available to the public and there are no application or eligibility requirements. The service can be used to get to work, appointments, grocery stores, entertainment, recreation, etc.  We will refer customers to use fixed route service first if it is available, accessible, and meets the need.

Our vehicles are dispatched to pick-up riders at different pick-up points before taking them to their respective destinations.  A rider may be the only passenger in the vehicle or riding with others if locations and times are similar.

Call 3-5 days in advance whenever possible to book your ride but no less than at least 24 hours. You can schedule up to a month in advance and the sooner you schedule, the more likely you are to get a ride.  Same-day ride requests are accommodated on a space-available basis.

Our schedulers group customers together based on time and space availability and while the service is available to all, preference will be given to people with urgent medical needs, individuals with disabilities, and seniors. Our goal is to meet our rider’s needs as closely as possible, while still being cost-effective.

Service hours: Monday – Friday, 6AM – 7PM
paratransit_55_description:
https://kingcounty.gov/depts/transportation/metro/travel-options/rideshare/programs/community-van.aspx

Local Calls: 206-625-4500
WA Relay: 711
Fax: 206-684-2166

How to drive
Support your neighbors, your community, and the environment by becoming a Community Van volunteer driver. You can choose which trips you drive and how many times a week you drive.

Become an approved Community Van volunteer
Email the completed application to your local coordinator (emails contained in the list of cities/jurisdictions under Schedule Your Ride) or King County Metro Community Van staff. If you have questions, email us or call us at 206-625-4500.

After receiving and reviewing your application Metro and your Community Transportation Coordinator will contact you to help you get started and on the road sharing community trips.

Driving a Community Van is good for you and your community—it gets you and your neighbors where they need to go and supports community travel by providing another public transportation choice at times and days you need it.

How to ride
Schedule your ride
Make a reservation to drive or to schedule a ride in a Community Van by contacting your local coordinator. Seven-passenger mini-vans and twelve-passenger and six-passenger ADA-accessible vans are available. Click on the service area links above or use the contact information below to get started:

Duvall-Carnation: Email Teresa Ngo or call 425-943-6721
Bothell-Woodinville: Email Kristi Dreessen or call 425-352-5129
Vashon: Email Lilie Corroon or call 206-773-7003
Kenmore-Kirkland: Email Blair Daly or call 425-587-3924
Sammamish: Email Rose Weiker or call 425-295-0646
Shoreline-Lake Forest Park: Email Teresa Ngo or call 425-943-6721
Algona-Pacific: Email Gary Klein or call 253-217-5000
Skyway: Email Kahdijah Jackson or call 206 304-8347
Phone translation is available when calling your local coordinator. Let your coordinator know you need translation to schedule your Community Van ride by saying the name of your language in English.

Pay for your ride
Your Metro fare covers round-trip Community Van transportation.

Adults (19 to 64 years)$2.75

Youth (0 to 18 years)FREE

ORCA LIFT Cardholders
(Income qualified)$1.00

RRFP cardholders
(registered seniors, Medicare, disabled)$1.00

Pay with Transit GO mobile tickets, any monthly ORCA card pass, or Human Services Bus Tickets.
We currently cannot accept other forms of payment including cash or ORCA card E-purse.
Accessibility
Wheelchairs
Wheelchair accessible Community Vans are available on request. Each wheelchair accessible van includes a ramp and wheelchair securement. Tell the Community Van Coordinator about your needs when you schedule your trip.

Youth
Youth 18 and under ride for free! Parents and guardians must provide and install any needed car seats for their accompanying children who require a car seat according to the Washington State Child Restraint Law.

Children 13 and under who are not riding with a parent need a completed child rider agreement signed by their parents in advance of the trip. Contact your local coordinator for form access.

For how long may I book the van?
Trips may be scheduled 24-hours-a-day, 7-days-a-week. Trips cannot be over night and vehicles must be returned the same day. Trip destinations should be within the city or county vehicle is assigned. Trips requests that do not meet these criteria will be reviewed case-by-case by your coordinator.
paratransit_56_description:
Is the lack of transportation prohibiting you from getting out to socialize or to enjoy a healthy meal? The GMVCC Van provides Maple Valley residents rides to and from the Community Center for programs. Service is available Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays from 9 am to 3 pm for those 55 years and older, disabled, or with limited income.

Van rides are $1 each way within GMVCC transportation boundaries. $20 bus passes (good for 20 rides) are available.

GMVCC prefers that users schedule transportation 1 week ahead of time. 
Users can schedule a minimum of 24 hours in advance, but it's subject to availability
transit_57_description:
The Circulating Shuttle is a FREE service connecting the citizens of Kent to their community. A joint effort between King County Metro Transit, the City of Kent, and Hopelink.

The shuttle travels in several loops to shopping areas, banks, medical facilities, and senior housing. Route Map
Every bus is equipped for wheelchairs and bikes.
Riders can also make reservations for special pick-ups.

How do I ride the Circulating Shuttle?

Buses arrive each half-hour in the downtown area and each hour on the East Hill, from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.. Monday through Saturday.
Originally called the Shopper Shuttle, some bus stops still display the Shopper Shuttle Frog logo. Traditional King County Metro Signs are used where other buses stop. The 914 and 916 are the route numbers for the Circulating Shuttle.
The Shuttle goes right to the front door of most of its destinations.
Drivers are trained to help passengers with their bags, walkers, and wheelchairs.
Drivers can also assist you with any questions in order to help you get to your destination
Schedule a pick-up: 866-261-3278 
Metro Rider Information: 206-553-3000
https://www.kentwa.gov/city-hall/public-works/transportation-and-streets/public-transit-and-commute-options/kent-s-free-circulating-shuttle
paratransit_59_description:
- Children of all ages under 18 ride for FREE. Youth 6 and older are encouraged to get a youth ORCA Card.
- Senior fares $1.25 with Regional Reduced Fare Permit (Seniors must be 65+)
- Disabilities or Medicare fares $1.25 (qualifying disability)
- ORCA LIFT (Income-qualified) fares $1.25
Save when you pay with your ORCA card. Travel up to two hours with just one fare! Get credit for your paid fare on additional Zip rides and trips on transit within two hours. 

https://www.communitytransit.org/zip

Note: this is not official Community Transit data
